image.altText: Lauren Hemp runs past Clare Polkinghorne

items.synopsis: Samantha Kerr's unbelievable strike brought Stadium Australia to its feet — but minutes later, the Matildas were left deflated thanks to the pressure from the player of the game.

title.children: Just minutes after Sam Kerr's stunning strike, England's star of the match knocked the wind out of Australia's World Cup hopes

image.altText: a large crowd gathering and letting off flares

items.synopsis: Football fans storm barricades and throw flares at Melbourne's Federation Square, which hit maximum capacity.

title.children: World Cup drama as fans storm barriers, throw flares at overflowing Federation Square

image.altText: Australia's football superstar Sam Kerr looks sad but gives a thumbs up to the crowd after the Matildas Women's World Cup loss.

items.synopsis: The Matildas call for improved funding for football and urge their plethora of new-found fans to stay on the bandwagon after the Women's World Cup.

title.children: 'We need funding everywhere': Sam Kerr, Matildas teammates call for investment, support for football after World Cup run

image.altText: A phone screen showing a mail app with two notifications

items.synopsis: Phishing is the most commonly reported scam in Australia, with scammers harvesting tens of millions of dollars every year from unsuspecting victims.

title.children: It was the most reported scam in Australia last year. Here's how phishing works

image.altText: A man in a mask sitting on a chair.

items.synopsis: An uprising inspired and led by women was met with a swift crackdown. Now, young dissidents speak to the ABC in a series of interviews conducted in secret.

title.children: Amir was shot. A friend was jailed. He locked himself in a room and came up with a plan

image.altText: An aerial shot of a dilapidated old warship.

items.synopsis: A dilapidated Philippines ship intentionally run aground on a South China Sea reef to counter China's claim to the area could soon "succumb to the elements", an American security analyst says.

title.children: Philippines in a race against time to resupply a rusting hulk in the South China Sea

image.altText: A blurred car driving on the highway with petrol prices showing behind it

items.synopsis: Australians are feeling more pain at the petrol pump as prices rise to the highest level so far this year, and analysts say the rising prices are likely to stay for "the next few weeks" at least.

title.children: Motorists are paying more for petrol now than they have all year — and it's likely to stay that way for weeks

image.altText: A soccer player wearing yellow and green holds her face in her hands with the result on the scoreboard behind

items.synopsis: The Matildas wanted to create their own Cathy Freeman moment. They did — but not in quite the way they expected.

title.children: Matildas' semifinal loss to England was not about the finish, but the run

image.altText: A group of Matildas players and coaches form a heart on the pitch as they talk after a big match.

items.synopsis: A Sam Kerr wonder goal, sure, but Australia's World Cup run is over as England ran out 3-1 winners in the Women's World Cup semi-final — here's how the internet reacted.

title.children: 'That’s a gift': How the internet reacted to the Matildas' heartbreaking 3-1 loss to England

image.altText: A large crowd of people waiting at a train station

items.synopsis: Commuters faced long delays getting home after the Matildas' loss to England in the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Police investigating after suspected vandalism causes commuter chaos following Matildas' World Cup loss

image.altText: Composite image of Ellie Carpenter, Sam Kerr and Lauren Hemp.

items.synopsis: The Matildas' FIFA World Cup dream has come to an end in a semifinal filled with moments of magic and critical errors. Here are five quick hits from England's win over Australia in Sydney.

title.children: Five quick hits — Kerr's brilliant goal and costly misses define semifinal as Hemp steals the show

image.altText: Indigenous man with grey hair and one eye looks into the distance

items.synopsis: Djiniyini Gondarra, a spiritual leader from north-east Arnhem Land, wants to see his decades-long calls for a treaty fulfilled. But he doesn't believe a Voice will deliver it.

title.children: He's been described as Australia's Gandhi. And this civil rights leader is planning to vote No to a Voice

image.altText: King Charles smiles and looks to the left.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Australia deemed 'weeping Matildas' by UK media, but 'magnificent' by King Charles. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former Matildas captain Kate Gill tells ABC News Breakfast that Australian soccer now needs to "focus" its attention on supporting A-League Women, off the back of momentum from the Matildas' inspriring push at the Women's World Cup. "[A-League Women] has been the breeding ground for the quality group of players that have come through into our Matildas team at the moment," she says. "So it's important that pathway keeps thriving and to do that we really need to transform it from a semi-amateur competition to a professional competition, and make sure that those players within that environment are full-time professionals and they are remunerated accordingly. "That is our talent pipeline. So we need to get behind and support that. I am hoping that all these fans that are rusted-on Matildas fans now can translate that enthusiasm and start turning up for our A-League Women's players as well."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former Matildas captain Kate Gill calls for fans to "turn up" for A-League Women's players

props.alt: A woman in a jumper and jacket gives a TV interview on Sydney Harbour

children.content: Former Matildas captain Kate Gill tells ABC News Breakfast that
Australian soccer now needs to "focus" its attention on supporting A-League Women
, off the back of momentum from the Matildas' inspriring push at the Women's World Cup.
"[A-League Women] has been the breeding ground for the quality group of players that have come through into our Matildas team at the moment," she says.

"So it's important that pathway keeps thriving and to do that we really need to transform it from a semi-amateur competition to a professional competition, and make sure that those players within that environment are full-time professionals and they are remunerated accordingly.

"That is our talent pipeline. So we need to get behind and support that. I am hoping that all these fans that are rusted-on Matildas fans now can translate that enthusiasm and start turning up for our A-League Women's players as well."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Swimming's governing body says it will debut a new "open category" for transgender swimmers at the World Cup in Berlin in October. Last year, World Aquatics voted to ban transgender athletes from competing in elite women's competitions at major events. World Aquatics says the open category will feature in 50-metre and 100-metre races across all strokes. It says more events could be added.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Open category' added for transgender swimmers at World Cup

children.content: Swimming's governing body says it will debut a new "open category" for transgender swimmers at the
World Cup in Berlin in October.
from competing in elite women's competitions at major events.
World Aquatics says the open category will feature in 50-metre and 100-metre races across all strokes.
It says more events could be added.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ukrainian officials say Russia is attacking their grain storage facilities, with air strikes damaging silos and warehouses at a port on the Danube river. There's been no comment from Moscow. US State Department deputy spokesperson Vedant Patel says Russia's attacks on Ukrainian port infrastructure are escalating food shortages. "[Russian President Vladimir] Putin simply does not care about global food security," he says. "Such actions by the Kremlin negatively affect Ukrainian farmers and all those around the world who are most vulnerable to food insecurity."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US condemns Russia's continued attacks on Ukraine's grain infrastructure

children.content: Ukrainian officials say Russia is attacking their grain storage facilities, with air strikes damaging silos and warehouses at a port on the Danube river.
There's been no comment from Moscow.
US State Department deputy spokesperson Vedant Patel says Russia's attacks on Ukrainian port infrastructure are escalating food shortages.
"[Russian President Vladimir] Putin simply does not care about global food security," he says.
"Such actions by the Kremlin negatively affect Ukrainian farmers and all those around the world who are most vulnerable to food insecurity."

image.altText: A young man with short, dark hair and a contemplative expression on his face stands in a field.

items.synopsis: Victorian police officer Alex Prestney was on duty the day his brother and four of their colleagues died in a horrific crash with an appalling aftermath. Now he's harnessing the passion he shared with his sibling to try and spare others the same pain.

title.children: His brother's death shocked the nation and sparked outrage. Alex says it could have been him

image.altText: A close-up of an embryo being surgically prodded

items.synopsis: Affected patients were alerted this week about the contamination at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital's fertility unit.

title.children: 'It's devastating': Embryos destroyed after bacterial outbreak at IVF clinic

image.altText: Dozens of people of all ages line up outside a "For Lease" sign at a Sydney apartment building.

items.synopsis: The rejection of a rental freeze at yesterday's National Cabinet means the push from the Greens has hit a dead end. Will the party join the Coalition to vote down the government's $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund? We'll see, writes David Speers.

title.children: Rental freeze hits a dead end, squashed by the orthodox view

image.altText: Stack of several thousand dollars worth of Australian $50 notes showing David Unaipon

items.synopsis: A survey of insolvency professionals, turnaround advisors, company boards and lawyers says sentiment among working professionals has fallen noticeably during a relatively short space of time.

title.children: Australian recession 'likely' in the next 12 months, according to new industry survey

image.altText: A computer-generated graphic of Anthony Albanese at a podium. Around him, a crowd of people hold up pamphlets.

items.synopsis: Labor voters descend on Brisbane to hash out their party's platform for the next three years, readying to debate some of the most contentious policies in federal politics.

title.children: The great Labor spectacle begins, as ALP hosts first national conference in government since Julia Gillard

image.altText: A school building with a sign in front of the building reading St Patricks College

items.synopsis: The principal of a prestigious Victorian school has written to staff and parents amid investigations into the behaviour of a staff member and claims of toxic workplace culture.

title.children: Principal of top private boys' school rejects claims of 'workplace cultural issues'

image.altText: Anthony Albanese speaks with state and territory leaders in a conference room.

items.synopsis: The prime minister has touted a "better deal for renters" and a blueprint to boost housing supply following a meeting with state and territory leaders in Brisbane.

title.children: National cabinet touts 'better deal for renters' but Greens slam moves as 'smoke and mirrors'

image.altText: A bulldog against a blue background. There are three red lines emanating from the dog's open mouth to show its barking

items.synopsis: Wind back the clock a few hundred million years, and landscapes were completely silent of any truly meaningful communication through sound. So when did animals first find their voice, so to speak, and why?

title.children: Silent landscapes were normal millions of years ago — and then animals began to 'speak'

image.altText: a young woman holding hospital equipment

items.synopsis: Ivy Belavy wanted a job that would help people. But the 19-year-old, who has a disability, found it difficult to get work.

title.children: Ivy found employers rarely 'had the patience for her'. Now she works in aged care

image.altText: A dark image with a blue lit stage in the distance and hundreds of people's silhouettes in front

items.synopsis: Georgia has a long history of tension with its northern neighbour, exacerbated by the conflict in Ukraine.

title.children: The Killers upset Georgian fans by bringing Russian on stage

image.altText: Volunteers helping residents to evacuate.

items.synopsis: Ukraine announces the recapture of the village of Urozhaine from Russian troops in the south-east, but warns the situation on the north-eastern front is deteriorating amid Russian counterattacks.

title.children: Ukraine recaptures key village from Russian forces but warns trouble on the north-eastern front

image.altText: Alana Young addresses the crowd through tears on Russell Island

items.synopsis: Five boys and their father were killed in the blaze, the state's worst house fire tragedy since 2011. Loved ones paid tribute to the "heroic" dad and his "beautiful" boys.

title.children: 'Real heartbreak is outliving children': Loved ones gather to mourn loss of five boys, father on Russell Island

image.altText: A toddle sticking out their red toungue.

items.synopsis: Queenslanders are being warned to be vigilant for fever and rash symptoms in young children as group A streptococcus infections sweep across the state.

title.children: Parents urged to watch for scarlet fever symptoms as strep A cases surge in Queensland

image.altText: A green and pink parrot on a perch inside a home

items.synopsis: When Conor Mulligan's pet parrot went missing in suburban Adelaide, he did what many pet owners do and distributed posters around the area, but never imagined it would lead to "one of the scariest situations" he had ever been in.

title.children: Conor offered a reward for his missing bird. Days later he was being ambushed

image.altText: A composite image of brothers Obaid and Shaheryer Khan, wearing suits outside court.

items.synopsis: Shaheryer and Obaid Khan are placed on a 12-month good behaviour bond after they were found in possession of 2.4 million counterfeit stamps when police raided their property in 2021.

title.children: Judge delivers good news for brothers caught up in multi-million-dollar postage stamp scam

image.altText: A man dribbles a basketball in front of his opponent.

items.synopsis: With the Basketball World Cup a little over a week away, the Boomers suffer a loss to Brazil in a warm-up match in Melbourne.

title.children: Boomers' World Cup preparations take a hit as Aussies lose to Brazil in warm-up clash

image.altText: Will Forte as Reggie behind the wheel of a car with a dog in the background. Doug looks exasperated

items.synopsis: Starring Will Ferrell, Jamie Foxx and Australian actor Isla Fisher, Strays is an R-rated comedy about friendship that will have you howling with laughter.

title.children: Strays will leave you roaring with laughter and gasping in disbelief

image.altText: A man with long white hair and white beard, with glasses, smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Sunil Badami remembers his uncle wowing the public with 'miracles' like bending spoons with his mind. Decades later, he learnt the devastating secret his uncle hid.

title.children: Sunil's uncle lived a public life, eating fire and levitating. But he carried a private grief

image.altText: A woman sits watching a speaker intently at a conference.

items.synopsis: An explosive memo written by Gina Rinehart, allegedly part of a "special project" to deflate the value of Hancock Prospecting shares, has been presented to the Supreme Court as part of a huge civil trial in Perth.

title.children: 'Egregious breach of duty': Gina Rinehart tried to deflate value of shares in family trust, court hears

image.altText: NSW Transport Minister Jo Haylen speaking at a press conference, with NSW Premier Chris Minns standing in the background.

items.synopsis: Josh Murray was hired to a $600k-a-year role despite an external recruiter finding he was underqualified.

title.children: 'Jobs for the boys': Transport minister under fire over controversial $600k hire

image.altText: An older man wearing a singlet and sunglasses takes a selfie at a beach.

items.synopsis: Newcastle District Court heard that Colin William Babbage, 65, threatened a 31-year-old woman with a knife before he sexually assaulted her in 2021. She was his fourth victim.

title.children: Serial rapist who has served almost 20 years behind bars jailed again

image.altText: Fire damage is shown in the Wahikuli Terrace neighborhood in the fire ravaged town of Lahaina

items.synopsis: The exact cause of the fire remains unknown, but some are pointing the finger at an electricity company for leaving its grid on amid high wind warnings and dozens of toppled poles.

title.children: Powerlines are being blamed for the Maui fires. If true, it's not without precedent
